5-4C-1: RUNNING AT LARGE PROHIBITED:
   A.   Definition: "Owner" or "keeper" as used herein shall mean any person
having a right of property in a dog or cat or who keeps or harbors a dog or cat
or who has a dog or cat in his or her care or acts as a custodian of a dog or
cat or who knowingly permits a dog or cat to remain on or about any premises
occupied by him or her.
   B.   Animals At Large:
      1.   Prohibited: No dog or cat shall be permitted or allowed to run at
large within the city and shall be confined at all times on the owner's or
keeper's premises, or on a leash or on the owner's or keeper's premises under
the control of a person physically able to control such dog or cat.
      2.   Declared Nuisance: If found running at large, the dog or cat is
hereby declared to be a public nuisance and shall be taken up and impounded by
the animal control officer or member of the police department in accordance
with the provisions of this article.
      3.   Subject To Impoundment: Every dog or cat running at large within the
city is subject to impoundment by the animal control officer.
      4.   Prima Facie Evidence: When any dog or cat shall be found running at
large in violation of the provisions herein, it shall be prima facie evidence
that the owner or keeper of said dog or cat allowed and permitted the animal to
run at large.
   C.   Penalty: Any person owning or keeping and permitting any dog or cat to
run at large and not keeping such animal confined at all times, except as
otherwise provided herein, on the owner's or keeper's premises shall be subject
to penalty as provided in section
1-4-1 of this code. (1997 Code)
5-4C-2: LICENSE REQUIRED:
   A.   Purchase Required: No dog or cat shall be permitted to be or remain in
the city without being licensed as herein provided.
   B.   Annual Registration; Tag: Every owner of or person who keeps or harbors
a dog or cat within the limits of the city shall report to the clerk annually,
within thirty (30) days after May 1 each year, his/her name and address, and
shall give the name, breed, month of birth, color and sex of each and every dog
or cat owned, kept and harbored by such person and shall pay such license fee
as required in section
5-4C-4 of this article for male or female dogs or cats owned, kept or harbored,
and shall cause such dogs or cats to be registered in the Office of the City
Clerk or animal control officer, who shall furnish the person paying the
license therefor with the metal tag or check as hereinafter provided.
   C.   Rabies Certificate: Every owner or person who harbors or keeps a dog or
cat within the limits of the City shall, before securing registration tags,
exhibit to the Clerk or animal control officer a current County rabies
certificate.
   D.   Penalty: Any person owning a dog or cat shall purchase a license as
herein provided or be subject to penalty as provided in section
1-4-1 of this Code. (1997 Code)
5-4C-3: LICENSE TAGS, COLLAR REQUIRED:
   A.   Registry: The City Clerk or animal control officer shall keep a
complete registry in a book kept for that purpose, of all licensed dogs or cats
describing the same by name, breed, color and sex, and shall also enter the
name and address of the owner or keeper as given, and the number of the City
license, tag or check.
   B.   Tags Provided By City: The City Clerk or animal control officer shall
also provide each and every year, such number of metal tags or checks as may be
necessary, having stamped thereon the year for which the license is issued, the
letters "C.A.T.", and also the number of the tag or check, and it shall be the
duty of the City Clerk or animal control officer to deliver one of such tags or
check numbered to correspond with the registry of the animal, to the person
having paid the license tax upon any such animal. The owner of each animal
being of the age of four (4) months or over must have a tag for such animal.
   C.   Collar Required: Every dog or cat over the age of four (4) months shall
be provided by its owner or keeper with a collar to which shall be securely
attached and kept the license registration tag furnished by the City Clerk or
animal control officer as hereinabove provided.
   D.   Removal Of Collars, Tags Or Leashes: No person, other than the animal
control officer, a police officer, or an owner shall remove the collar,
inoculation tag or leash from any dog or cat within the City without the
consent of the owner or keeper of the dog or cat. Any such removal shall
subject the dog or cat to impoundment. (1997 Code)
   E.   Penalty: Anyone found guilty of violating this section shall be subject
to penalty as provided in section
1-4-1 of this Code. (Ord. 0-19-01, 2-25-2019)
5-4C-4: FEES:
   A.   License Fee: An annual license fee for dogs and cats shall be
established by the City Council as may be necessary.
   B.   Violation Fees:
      1.   Failure To License Or Display License: The animal control officer
shall issue to the owner or keeper of any unlicensed dog or cat or the owner of
any dog or cat failing to display the license tag a notice of ordinance
violation.
      2.   Notice Of Ordinance Violation: A person receiving a notice of
ordinance violation may, at his/her discretion, pay to the animal control
officer within seven (7) working days a sum established by the administrative
fee schedule in subsection C of this section.
      3.   Failure To Comply: In the event no payment is received within the
time period prescribed by the animal control officer, a formal Municipal
ordinance violation complaint shall be initiated in the Circuit Court.
   C.   Administrative Fee Schedule: The animal control officer is authorized
to accept in full satisfaction of any notice of ordinance violation the payment
of the following administrative fees:
      1.   Twenty dollars ($20.00) for the first offense and forty dollars
($40.00) for each offense thereafter.
      2.   Proof of payment of fees imposed by section
5-4C-7 of this article.
      3.   The penalty for violating this section shall be a fine of twenty
five dollars ($25.00) for the first offense and a fine of fifty dollars
($50.00) for each offense thereafter. (1997 Code)
5-4C-5: LIMITATION ON NUMBER:
   A.   Number Allowed At Residence: No person in charge of a residence shall
keep, harbor or control more than four (4) dogs, four (4) cats, or a
combination of four (4) at his/her residence. (1997 Code; amd. Ord. 08-05, 6-
13-2005)
   B.   Unoccupied Residence: It shall be illegal and improper for any resident
or nonresident of the City of Colona to house or keep animals or pets of any
nature at a residence which is unoccupied. (Ord. 08-05, 6-13-2005)
   C.   Penalty: Anyone found guilty of violating this section shall be subject
to penalty as provided in section
1-4-1 of this Code. (Ord. 0-19-01, 2-25-2019)
5-4C-6: INOCULATION:
   A.   Inoculation Required: Each owner or keeper of any dog or cat within the
City shall cause the dog or cat to be inoculated by a licensed veterinarian and
shall maintain a current rabies inoculation for such dog or cat at all times.
Current status shall be determined by the rules and standards of the State
Department of Agriculture and by the United States Department of Agriculture.
   B.   Inoculation Tag: The animal control officer shall be the official
responsible for and charged with the duty of issuing the inoculation tag
evidencing the administration of a valid rabies inoculation required by
subsection A of this section.
   C.   Attachment To Collar: Each dog or cat kept within the City shall be
provided by its owner or keeper with a good and substantial collar, and shall
cause to be attached in a secure manner a current inoculation tag. The owner or
keeper shall at all times cause the dog or cat to wear the collar with
inoculation tag attached.
   D.   Removal Of Tag: Any dog or cat found within the City, but off of the
premises occupied by the owner of the dog or cat and not wearing a collar with
inoculation tag attached as required under this section shall be impounded and
disposed of as provided in this chapter. (1997 Code)
   E.   Penalty: Anyone found guilty of violating this section shall be subject
to penalty as provided in section
1-4-1 of this Code. (Ord. 0-19-01, 2-25-2019)
5-4C-7: IMPOUNDMENT; REDEMPTION:
   A.   Impounding: It shall be the duty of the animal control officer or the
officers of the Police Department to take up and impound, in such place as
shall be provided by the City Council for that purpose to be known as the
"animal pound", any dog or cat running at large within the City in violation of
section
5-4C-1 of this article.
   B.   Capture, Transporting:
      1.   Method Of Capture: The animal control officer and his/her assistants
shall be allowed the use of leashes, nets and tranquilizer guns as means of
taking up and impounding animals specified in this chapter. The use of a
tranquilizer gun shall be allowed only after an authorized individual has been
properly instructed in its use by a qualified instructor previously approved by
a majority vote of the City Council.
      2.   Transporting: The Animal Control Department shall provide means of
transporting impounded animals specified in this article from place of capture
to the pound. Transportation may include the use of:
         a.   A portable pen temporarily or permanently mounted in a vehicle
which is property of the animal control officer or his/her assistants; or
         b.   A portable pen temporarily or permanently mounted in a City-
owned vehicle assigned temporarily or permanently for animal control purposes;
or
         c.   A specially designed City-owned vehicle assigned for animal
control purposes.
   C.   Notice Of Impoundment:
      1.   Determination Of Ownership: When any dog or cat displaying an
inoculation tag, license tag, or tattoo registered with the City shall be
impounded, the animal control officer shall make a search of the City records
or contact the veterinarian who issued the inoculation tag to determine the
owner thereof and shall immediately provide the apparent owner thereof, if any,
with written notice. The notice shall be delivered by certified, return receipt
requested mail.
      2.   Notice: The notice provided for in subsection C1 of this section
shall be in the following or a similar form:
   NOTICE
You are hereby notified that a ( ) male ( ) female dog/cat ( ) believed to be
owned by you ( ) of which you are the registered licensed owner, has been
impounded by the Animal Control Officer of the City of Colona because the dog/
cat was found to be running at large ( ) with ( ) without a proper license.
As the owner of the dog/cat, you are liable for a fine up to seven hundred
fifty dollars ($750.00) for violation of Title 5, Chapter 4, Article C of the
City Code.
You may redeem the dog/cat upon showing the Animal Control Officer that the
dog/cat has been inoculated and upon payment of a redemption fee of $20.00 for
the first offense and $40.00 for each offense thereafter and the current tax if
the same is unpaid. Such fees shall be paid to the Animal Control Officer.
If redemption of the dog/cat is not made within seven (7) days from the time of
impoundment or by       A.M./P.M. on                 , the dog/cat shall be
disposed of in accordance with the provisions of subsection 5-4C-7H of the City
Code.
You are hereby notified that if you do not appear within five (5) days of the
date of this notice, I will appear before the Circuit Court of Henry County and
sign a complaint formally charging you with violation of Title 5, Chapter 4,
Article C of the City Code.
                                           
         Animal Control Officer
D. Care Of Impounded Animals:
1. Shelter: Sufficient shelter shall be furnished in which to cause retention
and in which to sustain or improve the health of impounded animals.
2. Food: Sufficient feeding shall be furnished to sustain or improve the health
of impounded animals.
3. First Aid; Medical Care: Necessary first aid and medical care shall be
furnished to sustain or improve the health of impounded animals.
E. Redemption: Any dog or cat taken up and confined in the City- authorized
animal pound may be redeemed by the owner or keeper thereof any time within
seven (7) days from the time the same was impounded, upon payment of the
following fees:
1. A redemption fee of twenty dollars ($20.00) for the first offense and forty
dollars ($40.00) for each offense thereafter;
2. The amount of the current veterinarian inoculation fee unless current
inoculation is proven;
3. The license fee imposed by section
5-4C-4 of this article unless valid license is proven;
4. Both the redemption fee and impoundment fee shall be waived for animals
which were licensed at the time of impoundment and which have not previously
been impounded.
F. Removal Without Paying Fees: Any owner or keeper who shall take said dog or
cat from such animal pound without payment of the fees prescribed herein shall
be subject to the penalties provided for in section
1-4-1 of this Code.
G. Exempt Animals: It shall be the discretion of the animal control officer to
exempt animals violating the provisions of this article after being shown by
the owner or keeper proof of restraint or failure.
H. Disposition Of Unclaimed Animals: All dogs or cats not redeemed within seven
(7) days from the time the same was impounded shall, under the direction of the
Chief of Police or animal control officer be destroyed by a qualified employee
or veterinarian.
I. Liability Of Owners Or Keepers: Owners or keepers identified of unclaimed
animals will be held liable for all expenses incurred including pickup fees,
boarding fees, euthanasia and disposal of such animal. Owner or keeper will
also be held liable for any other expenses such as attorney fees that may arise
due to the animal remaining unclaimed. (1997 Code)
5-4C-8: INJURED ANIMALS:
A. Picked Up By Animal Control Officer: The animal control officer shall remove
from any street or public place within the City any injured dog or cat not
being attended and properly cared for by the owner and shall, if the animal
control officer deems it advisable, impound and confine the dog or cat with
some veterinarian within the City.
B. Veterinary Costs: If the veterinarian shall treat the injured dog or cat,
the veterinarian shall advise the animal control officer of the cost of the
treatment and in the event such dog or cat is redeemed as provided in this
article, the person redeeming the dog or cat shall pay the charges of the
veterinarian.
C. Unredeemed Animal: If the dog or cat is not redeemed, it shall be disposed
of in the manner provided in this article. (1997 Code)
5-4C-9: ANIMALS IN ESTRUS:
No owner or keeper of any female dog or cat shall permit the dog or cat to run
at large within the City while in "heat". Any female dog or cat found running
at large should be taken up and impounded in the animal pound and the dog or
cat shall be disposed of, or may be redeemed upon the payment of the same fees
and in the same manner as dogs and cats may be redeemed which have been
impounded. Anyone found guilty of violating this section shall be subject to
penalty as provided in section
1-4-1 of this Code. (1997 Code; amd. Ord. 0-19-01, 2-25-2019)
5-4C-10: DISTURBING THE PEACE:
No person shall permit, allow, keep, or harbor in such a way as to permit or
allow any dog or cat to unduly disturb the quiet of a neighborhood within the
City. Any dog or cat that unduly disturbs the quiet of a neighborhood is
declared to be a nuisance. (1997 Code)
5-4C-11: ANIMAL BITES:
A. Notification Of Bite; Leaving City Prohibited: No owner or keeper of any dog
or cat, when notified that such dog or cat has bitten any person or has so
injured any person as to cause an abrasion of the skin, shall sell or give away
such dog or cat or permit or allow the dog or cat to be taken beyond the limits
of the City. (1997 Code)
B. Confinement; Cost: It shall be the duty of the owner or keeper, upon
receiving notice of such an injury caused by the dog or cat, from the animal
control officer, or otherwise, to surrender possession of the dog or cat to the
animal control officer for confinement at a licensed veterinary clinic in the
City for not less than ten (10) days, the cost of such confinement to be paid
by the owner or keeper. Anyone found guilty of violating this section shall be
subject to penalty as provided in section
1-4-1 of this Code. (1997 Code; amd. Ord. 0-19-01, 2-25-2019)
5-4C-12: VICIOUS ANIMALS:
5-4C-12-1: DEFINITIONS:
For the purpose of this section
5-4C-12, the following terms and phrases shall have the meanings set forth in
this section:
BITE: To seize or cut with the teeth.
CONFINEMENT STRUCTURE: A securely locked pen, kennel or structure designed and
constructed for the keeping of a vicious dog shall be designed, constructed and
maintained in accordance with the standards herein. Such pen, kennel or
structure must have secure sides and a secure top attached to the sides. All
structures used to confine a City registered and licensed vicious dog must be
locked with a key or combination lock when such animals are within the
structure. Such structure must have a secure bottom or floor attached to the
sides of the pen or the sides must be embedded in the ground no less than two
feet (2'). All structures erected to house vicious dogs must comply with all
zoning and building regulations of the City. All such structures erected to
house vicious dogs must be adequately lighted, ventilated and kept in a clean
and sanitary condition.
FIGHT: A prearranged conflict between two (2) or more animals but does not
include a conflict that is unorganized or accidental.
K-9 PATROL OR POLICE DOG: A professionally trained dog used by law enforcement
officers for law enforcement and activities.
LEASH: A cord, chain, rope, strap, or other such physical restraint having a
tensile strength of not less than three hundred (300) pounds.
MUZZLE: A device constructed of strong, soft material or a metal muzzle. The
muzzle must be made in a manner which will not cause injury to the dog or
interfere with its vision or respiration, but must prevent it from biting any
person or animal.
NIP: To pinch or squeeze with teeth with no breaking of skin or tissue.
RUNNING AT LARGE: The failure to confine a vicious dog in accordance with
section
5-4C-1 of this article.
VICIOUS DOG: Any dog that has, without provocation attacked a human being or
other animal, or a dog that by its behavior or physical condition constitutes
an immediate and serious physical or health threat to human beings or animals,
or any dog which has previously attacked or bitten any human being or other
animal on two (2) or more reported occasions, or a dog that has been determined
to be a vicious or dangerous dog as set forth in section
5-4C-12-2 of this article. (Ord. 0-11-14, 7-14-2014)
5-4C-12-2: DETERMINED DANGEROUS:
A. Notice Of Determination: When in the judgment of the animal control officer
a dog may pose a danger or threat to the safety of the residents of the city by
reason of the dog's actions or past conduct, the animal control officer may
issue to the owner or keeper of such dog a written notice stating that the
animal control officer has deemed such dog to be a threat or danger to the
residents of the city and set forth the reasons for that judgment.
B. Failure To Comply: Failure of the owner or keeper of such dog to comply with
the requirements of this section
5-4C-12 in the time set by the animal control officer shall constitute a
violation of this section
5-4C-12 and each day the owner or keeper of such dog fails to comply with the
requirements of this section
5-4C-12 shall constitute a new violation. (Ord. 0-11-14, 7-14-2014)
5-4C-12-3: LICENSING:
A. License Required: No person shall possess any vicious dog for a period of
more than forty eight (48) hours without having first obtained a license
therefor from the city.
B. Application; Fee: An application for a license to possess a vicious dog
shall be filed with the Colona police department on a form prescribed and
provided by the Colona police department and shall be accompanied by all of the
following:
1. Verification Of Identity Of Owner: Verification of the identity of the owner
and current address by providing a photostatic copy of the owner's driver's
license.
2. Proof Of Ownership: Proof of ownership of the vicious dog.
3. Current Immunization And Health Records: A copy of the current immunization
and health record of the vicious dog by a veterinarian licensed to practice in
the state.
4. Certificate Of Insurance: A certificate of insurance evidencing coverage in
an amount not less than three hundred thousand dollars ($300,000.00) providing
coverage for any injury, damage or loss caused by the vicious dog.
5. Photographs: Two (2) photographs of the vicious dog to be licensed taken not
less than one month before the application. One photograph shall provide a
front view of the vicious dog and shall clearly show the face and ears of the
vicious dog. One photograph shall show a side view of the vicious dog.
6. License Fee: A license fee of twenty five dollars ($25.00).
7. Additional Information: Such other information as may be required by the
animal control officer.
8. Annual Submittal: All fees, inspections and licensing requirements of this
subsection B are due annually.
C. Inspection Of Premises: Upon receipt of an application, the police
department shall forward such application to the animal control officer who
shall cause an inspection of the premises on which the vicious dog shall be
kept to determine that all provisions of this section
5-4C-12 relating to the confinement and posting of signs have been complied
with by the applicant. Upon completion of the inspection, the animal control
officer shall notify the Colona police department in writing of the results of
his/her inspection.
D. Approval/Denial Of Application: Upon receipt of the results of the animal
control officer's inspection the animal control officer shall notify the
applicant of the approval or denial of the license. In the event the animal
control officer is not available the chief of police will designate another
employee of the Colona police department who shall notify the applicant of the
approval or denial of the license. In the event that the license is denied, the
notification shall be provided in writing and the reasons for such denial shall
be stated. Upon approval, the Colona police department shall issue a license to
the applicant. (Ord. 0-11-14, 7-14-2014)
5-4C-12-4: CONFINEMENT:
No person shall possess any vicious dog unless the vicious dog is confined in
accordance with this section.
A. Indoors: No vicious dog may be kept on a porch, patio or in any part of a
house or structure that would allow the vicious dog to exit the structure when
the windows are open or when screen windows or screen doors are the only
obstacle preventing the vicious dog from exiting the structure.
B. Exterior Yard: No person shall confine a vicious dog in an exterior area
unless such vicious dog is confined in a confinement structure constructed and
maintained in accordance with this section
5-4C-12, except that a vicious dog may be confined outside of a confinement
structure in a manner set forth in subsection C of this section.
C. Leash: No person shall permit a vicious dog to go outside a confinement
structure, house or other structure unless the vicious dog is securely
restrained with a leash no longer than three feet (3') in length and fitted
with a muzzle. No person shall permit a vicious dog to be kept on a leash
unless a person is in physical control of the leash. No leash restraining any
vicious dog shall be attached to any inanimate object including, but not
limited to, trees, posts, stakes, and buildings. (Ord. 0-11-14, 7-14-2014)
5-4C-12-5: REPORTING REQUIREMENTS OF LICENSEE:
Any person holding a license pursuant to this section
5-4C-12 shall report the incidence of any of the following events:
A. Change In Ownership; Death: The sale, barter, exchange, gift or death of any
vicious dog shall be reported within forty eight (48) hours.
B. Escape; Theft: The escape from confinement or theft of any vicious dog shall
be reported upon discovery of the escape or theft.
C. Biting Or Nipping: Biting or nipping of any person or animal by a vicious
dog shall be reported upon occurrence.
D. Birth Of Offspring: The birth of any offspring of a vicious dog shall be
reported within forty eight (48) hours of the birth of the offspring.
E. Permanent Removal: The permanent removal of any vicious dog from the
territorial limits of the city shall be reported within forty eight (48) hours
of such removal by surrender of the license of the owner to the city clerk.
Except as provided in this section, the report of any incident required to be
reported under this section shall be made to the animal control officer. (Ord.
0-11-14, 7-14-2014)
5-4C-12-6: SIGN REQUIRED:
All persons possessing a vicious dog shall display in a prominent place on the
premises where the vicious dog is to be kept a sign which is readable by the
public from a distance of not less than one hundred feet (100') using the words
"Beware Of Vicious Dog". A similar sign shall be posted on a confinement
structure. (Ord. 0-11-14, 7-14-2014)
5-4C-12-7: FIGHTING PROHIBITED:
No person shall fight or bait, conspire to fight or bait, or keep, train, or
transport for the purpose of fighting or baiting, any pit bull dog and/or
vicious dog. (Ord. 0-11-14, 7-14-2014)
5-4C-12-8: IMPOUNDMENT:
A. Vicious Dog: Any dog which by its actions is a "vicious dog" as defined
herein shall be subject to immediate impoundment by the animal control officer
in a humane facility for the keeping of dogs. If the incident giving rise to
the impoundment has resulted in an injury to a person, upon impoundment by the
animal control officer, the chief of police or his/her designee shall notify
the rabies control administrator of the county pursuant to 510 Illinois
Compiled Statutes 5/12, and shall transfer control of the vicious dog to the
administrator in accordance with 510 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/13.
B. Running At Large: Any known vicious dog found to be running at large by the
animal control officer or any member of the police department shall be presumed
to be in violation of this section
5-4C-12 and shall be subject to impoundment by the animal control officer in a
humane facility for the keeping of dogs.
C. Redemption: An owner of a vicious dog holding a license pursuant to this
section
5-4C-12 may redeem an impounded vicious dog if: 1) a vicious dog has been
impounded pursuant to this section, or 2) a vicious dog has not caused injury
to a person subject to the following conditions:
1. Proof of a valid license issued by the City under this section
5-4C-12.
2. Payment of the cost of keeping the vicious dog during the period of
impoundment.
An owner of a vicious dog which has caused an injury to a person resulting in
the impoundment of the vicious dog shall be entitled to redeem the vicious dog
in accordance with 510 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/12. (Ord. 0-11-14, 7-14-
2014)
5-4C-12-9: REVOCATION OF LICENSE:
A license granted pursuant to this section
5-4C-12 shall be automatically revoked upon any violation by the licensee of
any provision of this section
5-4C-12. In the event of a revocation of the license, the license fee shall be
retained by the City. Upon revocation of license, owner of said animal shall
have twenty four (24) hours to remove the animal from the City. (1997 Code)
5-4C-12-10: EXCEPTIONS:
This section
5-4C-12 shall not apply to any "K-9 patrol dogs" or "police dogs" as defined
herein. (1997 Code)
5-4C-12-11: PENALTY:
A. Violation: Upon conviction of a violation of any section or subsection of
this section
5-4C-12, the court shall assess a fine as provided in section
1-4-1 of this Code.
B. Court Order: Upon a finding by the court that a licensee has violated
section
5-4C-12-4,
5-4C-12-5 or
5-4C-12-7 of this section
5-4C-12, the City shall enter an order revoking the license and ordering the
former holder of the license to remove the pit bull dog and/or vicious dog from
the City. (1997 Code)
5-4C-13: PROCEDURE FOR SUSPECTED RABIES:
Any dog or cat having symptoms of the disease known as rabies shall be confined
under the supervision of a veterinarian for a period of ten (10) days. Any dog
or cat having any symptoms of rabies when impounded by the animal control
officer shall be immediately placed in the care of a veterinarian. If it shall
be deemed that the dog or cat is suffering from rabies, the animal may not be
destroyed without specific authorization of the veterinarian. Anyone found
guilty of violating this section shall be subject to penalty as provided in
section
1-4-1 of this Code. (1997 Code; amd. Ord. 0-19-01, 2-25-2019)
5-4C-14: DESTROYING ANIMALS:
Whoever wilfully and maliciously abandons, kills, wounds, maims, disfigures or
poisons any dog or cat or exposes poisonous substances with the intent that the
life of any dog or cat should be destroyed thereby, such dog or cat being the
property of another or said owner or keeper himself/herself, shall be subject
to the penalties provided for in this Code. Anyone found guilty of violating
this section shall be subject to penalty as provided in section
1-4-1 of this Code. (1997 Code; amd. Ord. 0-19-01, 2-25-2019)
5-4C-15: MONTHLY REPORT:
The animal control officer shall, on a monthly basis, make a report to the City
Council of all fees, fines, and warrants; and shall keep a log of all calls and
further report said calls on said log. (1997 Code)
5-4C-16: KENNELING DOGS IN FRONT YARDS:
A. It shall be unlawful to kennel, house, chain, tie up, or otherwise keep a
dog or dogs in any part of the front yard of a property being used as a
residence.
B. "Front yard" shall be defined as an open space extending the full width of a
lot between a building and the front lot line, unoccupied and unobstructed from
the ground upward.
C. The property owner, all occupants of the residence, and the owners of the
dog or dogs shall each be jointly and/or severally liable for compliance with
this section.
D. Any property not in compliance with this section shall be brought into
compliance within sixty (60) days after the effective date hereof.
E. Should any portion of this section be deemed illegal, then only that portion
of the section that is illegal shall be stricken and all other portions shall
remain in full force and effect.
F. Each day the violation exists is a separate offense.
G. The fine for violating this section is not less than fifty dollars ($50.00)
nor more than five hundred dollars ($500.00).
H. Violation of this section shall also be part of the "no contest" procedure
and ordinance previously enacted. The "no contest" fine shall be seventy five
dollars ($75.00). (Ord. 98-10, 11-9-1998)
I. Any property owner, occupant of the residence or the dog owner may petition
the Colona Police Commission for a variance from this section if the layout or
construction of the residence makes compliance with this section impossible or
impractical. The Colona Police Commission shall conduct a hearing on the
petition at which time the petitioner may informally present evidence. If the
commission finds the compliance is impossible or impractical then a variance
may be granted under such terms and conditions as it sees fit. The commission
shall issue a written decision and mail a copy to the petitioner when issued.
Any notice of appeal to the Police Commission's decision must be filed with the
City Clerk within ten (10) days of issuance of the written decision of the
Police Commission. The appeal will be scheduled for review by the full City
Council within forty (40) days of the filing of the notice of appeal. The City
Council will review the findings of the Police Commission and issue written
findings and decision. The decision will be final and appealable upon signing
by the Mayor. (Ord. 98-10, 11-9-1998; amd. Ord. 0-15-001, 3-24-2015)
CHAPTER 5
FINES
SECTION:
5-5-1: No Contest Fine
5-5-2: Geometric Progression Of Fine
5-5-1: NO CONTEST FINE:
In the event that a person is accused of a violation and does not wish to
contest said allegation, then said person so accused may pay to the City at
police headquarters or pay online within fourteen (14) days from the date of
the citation (the date of issuance included) for and in full satisfaction of
said violation a fine in the amount of the minimum penalty, which minimum
penalty shall be one hundred dollars ($100.00) unless otherwise listed in this
Code 1 . In the event the accused person avails himself or herself of the
foregoing provisions of this section, then no court appearance, court costs,
administrative hearing appearance or administrative hearing costs shall be
required.
(Ord. 0-18-04, 1-22-2018; amd. Ord. O-20-06, 1-27-2020)
 
Notes
1 1. See also subsection 1-4-1A of this Code.
5-5-2: GEOMETRIC PROGRESSION OF FINE:
Ordinance violation fees and/or fines assessed under no contest offenses shall
be doubled for repeat offenders during the period of twelve (12) months
following the date of their last ticket for the same offense. Every violation
fee continues to double until a twelve (12) month period of being violation
free of the same offense.
Example: A March 2010 ticket followed by a September 2010 ticket for the same
offense: If March fine was twenty five dollars ($25.00) the September fine
would be fifty dollars ($50.00) and if a third ticket is incurred within twelve
(12) months the September ticket and fine would be one hundred dollars
($100.00) and the doubling of the last fine shall continue until the arrested
person is free of such offense for a twelve (12) month period following their
last ticket for the offense. (Ord. 0-15-10, 5-10-2010)
TITLE 6
MOTOR VEHICLES AND TRAFFIC
CHAPTER 1
GENERAL TRAFFIC PROVISIONS 1
SECTION:
6-1-1: Definitions
6-1-2: Illinois Vehicle Code Adopted
6-1-3: Speed Limit
6-1-4: Obedience To Police

6-1-7: Animals Or Bicycles
